info.name: ROS 2 Medkit Gateway API
info.description: Collection for ROS 2 Medkit Gateway REST API endpoints

item.name: Authentication
item.description: JWT authentication endpoints (REQ_INTEROP_086, REQ_INTEROP_087). OAuth2-compatible token management with RBAC support. Roles: viewer (read-only), operator (+ trigger operations), configurator (+ modify configs), admin (full access).

request.description: Authenticate using client credentials (REQ_INTEROP_086). Returns access_token, refresh_token, token_type, expires_in, and scope. Tokens are automatically saved to environment variables. Supported Content-Types: application/json, application/x-www-form-urlencoded.
Authenticate using form URL-encoded body (OAuth2 standard format). Alternative to JSON body.

Refresh an expired access token using a refresh token (REQ_INTEROP_087). Returns new access_token. The refresh_token remains valid until its expiry. New access token is automatically saved to environment.

exec: console.log('Tokens revoked and cleared from environment');

request.description: Revoke a refresh token (REQ_INTEROP_087). Invalidates the refresh token and all access tokens derived from it. Environment tokens are cleared on success.
Example of authentication failure with invalid credentials. Returns 401 with OAuth2 error response (error, error_description).
Example of authentication failure with unknown client. Returns 401 with error='invalid_client'.
Example of unsupported grant type. Only 'client_credentials' is supported for /auth/authorize. Returns 400 with error='unsupported_grant_type'.
Get server capabilities and entry points (REQ_INTEROP_010). Returns server name, version, available endpoints, and capabilities.

Get SOVD server version information. Returns sovd_info array with supported SOVD versions, base URIs, and vendor information. Response format: { sovd_info: [{ version, base_uri, vendor_info: { version, name } }] }
List all discovered areas (powertrain, chassis, body, root)

List all discovered components across all areas. Returns component metadata including id, namespace, fqn, type, area, source (node or topic), and available operations (services and actions). The 'source' field indicates whether the component was discovered from a ROS 2 node ('node') or from topic namespaces ('topic' - for systems like Isaac Sim).
List components within a specific area. Returns 404 if area doesn't exist. Change 'powertrain' to other areas like 'chassis', 'body', etc.

Get the list of components that the addressed component depends on (REQ_INTEROP_008). Returns array of component references with id, href, name, type, and missing flag (if dependency is unresolved). The 'engine-ecu' component depends on 'temp-sensor-hw' and 'rpm-sensor-hw' in the demo manifest.
Example of requesting dependencies for a non-existent component. Returns 404.
List all components contained within an area (SOVD 7.6.2.4). Returns EntityReference array with id, name, href.
List all apps hosted on a component (SOVD 7.6.2.4). Returns EntityReference array with id, name, href.

Read all topic data from a specific component. Returns array of topic samples with metadata (topic, timestamp, data). Change 'temp_sensor' to other component IDs like 'rpm_sensor', 'pressure_sensor', etc.
Read specific topic data from a component. Returns single topic sample with topic path, timestamp, and data. The topic_name is relative to the component's namespace.
Read RPM topic data from the rpm_sensor component.
Read brake pressure topic data from the pressure_sensor component.

Publish data to a component topic (REQ_INTEROP_020). Request body must contain 'type' (ROS 2 message type) and 'data' (message payload). Returns publish confirmation with topic, type, status, and timestamp.
Publish temperature data to the temp_sensor component. Example of publishing sensor_msgs/msg/Temperature type.
List all operations (services and actions) for a specific component. Returns array of operations with name, path, type, kind (service/action), and type_info with schema information.

Call a ROS 2 service operation on a component. This example calls the std_srvs/srv/Trigger calibrate service. The service type is auto-discovered from the component's registered services. Response includes execution id, status, and service response in x-medkit extension.

item.name: POST Call Service with Type Override

request.description: Call a ROS 2 service with explicit type override. Use 'type' field to specify the service type (e.g., 'std_srvs/srv/Trigger') and 'request' field for the service request data. Useful when the service type cannot be auto-discovered.
Example of calling a non-existent operation. Returns 404 error with 'Operation not found' message.

Start an async action operation. Sends a goal to the action server and returns 202 Accepted with execution id. Response includes execution id, status (running), and action details in x-medkit extension. Poll GET /executions/{id} to check status.
Send a short action goal (order=3 completes in ~1.5s). Returns 202 Accepted with execution id. If the action completes within timeout, status will be 'completed' when you poll.
List all executions for this operation. Returns an array of executions sorted by most recent first.
Get the status of a specific execution by execution_id. Returns status (running/completed/failed/cancelled), capability, and x-medkit extension with ROS 2 details.
Cancel a running action execution. Sends cancel request to the action server. Returns 204 No Content on success (SOVD compliant). Only works for running action executions.
List all parameters (configurations) for a component. Returns component_id, node_name, and array of parameters with name, value, and type. Maps to SOVD Configurations API.
Get a specific parameter value for a component. Returns component_id and parameter object with name, value, type, description, and read_only flag.
Get the min_temp parameter value from the temp_sensor component.

Set a parameter value for a component. Request body must contain 'value' field. Returns status, component_id, and updated parameter object. The value type is automatically converted to match the existing parameter type.
Change the publish rate of the temp_sensor component. Default is 2.0 Hz, valid range is 0.1-100.0 Hz. The demo node will dynamically update its timer.

Reset a configuration to its default (initial) value. The gateway caches parameter values when first accessed, allowing reset to the original state. Returns the parameter with reset_to_default=true and the restored value.

item.name: DELETE Reset All Configurations to Default

request.description: Reset all configurations for a component to their default (initial) values. Returns reset_count and failed_count. Some parameters may fail to reset if they are read-only.
Example of requesting a non-existent parameter. Returns 404 with error details.

item.name: Faults
item.description:
Fault management API for reporting, querying, and clearing faults.

**Features:**
- Query faults by status (pending/confirmed/cleared)
- Real-time SSE streaming for fault events
- Topic snapshots captured at fault confirmation
- **Fault Correlation**: Automatic root-cause analysis and fault clustering (configure via correlation.config_file parameter)

request.description:
Server-Sent Events (SSE) stream for real-time fault notifications.

Events:
- fault_confirmed: Fault transitioned to CONFIRMED status
- fault_cleared: Fault was manually cleared
- fault_updated: Fault data changed (occurrence_count, sources)

SSE Format:
```
event: fault_confirmed
data: {"event_type":"fault_confirmed","fault":{...},"timestamp":1234567890.123}
```

Note: Postman has limited SSE support. For testing, use:
- Browser: `new EventSource('http://localhost:8080/api/v1/faults/stream')`
- curl: `curl -N {{base_url}}/faults/stream`

Features:
- Keepalive every 30 seconds
- Reconnection support via Last-Event-ID header
- Multiple simultaneous clients supported

List all faults across the entire system. Convenience API for dashboards and monitoring tools. By default returns PENDING and CONFIRMED faults.

**Correlation fields (always included when correlation enabled):**
- `muted_count`: Number of symptom faults muted by correlation rules
- `cluster_count`: Number of active fault clusters

Use `include_muted=true` or `include_clusters=true` for detailed correlation data.
List all faults across the system including cleared ones. Use status=pending, status=confirmed, status=cleared, status=healed, or status=all to filter.
List all faults for a component (REQ_INTEROP_012). Returns component_id, source_id (namespace), faults array, and count. By default returns PREFAILED and CONFIRMED faults.
List all faults including cleared ones. Use status=prefailed, status=confirmed, status=cleared, status=healed, or status=all to filter.
Get a specific fault by fault_code (REQ_INTEROP_013). Returns component_id and fault object with fault_code, severity, severity_label, description, status, timestamps, and reporting_sources.

Clear a fault by fault_code (REQ_INTEROP_015). Changes fault status to CLEARED. Returns success status with component_id and fault_code.

**With correlation enabled:**
If the cleared fault is a root cause with `auto_clear_with_root=true`, the response includes `auto_cleared_codes[]` listing all symptom faults that were automatically cleared.

Clear all faults across the entire system (ros2_medkit extension, not SOVD).

Accepts the optional `?status=` query parameter (same values as GET /faults). Without it, clears active faults (pending + confirmed).

**Response codes:**
- 204: Faults cleared (or none to clear)
- 400: Invalid status parameter
- 503: Fault manager unavailable

query.description: Clear all faults including cleared/healed ones

request.description: Clear all faults across the system including all statuses (pending, confirmed, cleared, healed). Use status=pending, status=confirmed, status=cleared, status=healed, or status=all to filter.
Example of requesting a non-existent fault. Returns 404 with error details.

List faults with full correlation data. When correlation is enabled:

**Response always includes:**
- `muted_count`: Number of faults muted as symptoms of root causes
- `cluster_count`: Number of active fault clusters

**With include_muted=true:**
- `muted_faults[]`: Array of muted fault details (fault_code, root_cause_code, rule_id, delay_ms)

**With include_clusters=true:**
- `clusters[]`: Array of cluster details (cluster_id, representative_code, fault_codes[], rule_name, first_at, last_at)

**Correlation Modes:**
1. HIERARCHICAL: Identifies root cause â†’ symptom relationships. Symptoms are muted.
2. AUTO_CLUSTER: Groups similar faults within a time window into clusters.

item.name: GET Faults with Muted Details Only

request.description:
List faults with muted fault details. Muted faults are symptoms that were suppressed because a root cause was detected.

Each muted fault includes:
- `fault_code`: The symptom fault code
- `root_cause_code`: The root cause that triggered muting
- `rule_id`: Which correlation rule matched
- `delay_ms`: Time delay from root cause to symptom

item.name: GET Faults with Cluster Details Only

request.description:
List faults with cluster details. Clusters are groups of similar faults that occurred within a time window.

Each cluster includes:
- `cluster_id`: Unique cluster identifier
- `rule_id`, `rule_name`: The auto-cluster rule that created this cluster
- `representative_code`: The fault shown as the cluster representative (based on rule config: first, most_recent, or highest_severity)
- `representative_severity`: Severity of the representative fault
- `fault_codes[]`: All fault codes in the cluster
- `first_at`, `last_at`: Timestamps of first and last faults in cluster

Get topic snapshots captured when a fault transitioned to CONFIRMED status. Snapshots provide system state at the moment of fault confirmation for post-mortem debugging. Returns object with fault_code, captured_at timestamp, and topics object keyed by topic name containing message_type and parsed data.
Get snapshots filtered by specific topic name. Use this when you only need data from a particular topic.
Get topic snapshots for a specific component's fault. Same as the system-wide endpoint but scoped to a component context. Useful when working within a component-centric workflow.

item.name: Apps
item.description: App entity endpoints for heuristic discovery mode. In heuristic mode, ROS 2 nodes are exposed as Apps with source='heuristic'. Apps have is_online=true when the corresponding node is running.

request.description: List all discovered apps. In heuristic mode, ROS 2 nodes are exposed as Apps with source='heuristic'. Apps have is_online=true when the corresponding node is running.
Get details of a specific app including capabilities, links, and online status.
Get all topics published/subscribed by the app.
List all operations (services and actions) for the app.
Call a service operation on an app.
List all parameters (configurations) for the app.
Get a specific parameter value for an app.
Set a parameter value for an app.
Reset a configuration to its default value for an app.
List all faults reported by the app.
Get details of a specific fault for an app.
Clear a fault for an app.
Example of requesting a non-existent app. Returns 404.

item.name: LIDAR Fault Workflow
item.description: Complete fault management workflow using the demo LIDAR sensor. The sensor starts with intentionally invalid parameters that generate faults. This workflow demonstrates: (1) reading faults, (2) fixing parameters, (3) clearing faults, and (4) running calibration.

request.description:
Step 1: Check initial faults on the LIDAR sensor. Expected faults:
- LIDAR_RANGE_INVALID (ERROR): min_range > max_range
- LIDAR_FREQ_UNSUPPORTED (WARN): scan_frequency > 20.0 Hz
- LIDAR_CALIBRATION_REQUIRED (INFO): sensor not calibrated

Step 2: Check current parameter values. Initial values are intentionally invalid:
- min_range: 10.0 (invalid: greater than max_range)
- max_range: 5.0 (invalid: less than min_range)
- scan_frequency: 25.0 (unsupported: exceeds 20.0 Hz)
Step 3a: Fix min_range to a valid value (0.1m). This should be less than max_range.
Step 3b: Fix max_range to a valid value (30.0m). This should be greater than min_range.
Step 3c: Fix scan_frequency to a supported value (10.0 Hz). Maximum supported is 20.0 Hz.
Step 4a: Clear the range invalid fault now that parameters are fixed.
Step 4b: Clear the frequency unsupported fault now that scan_frequency is valid.
Step 5: Run LIDAR calibration service. This sets is_calibrated=true internally, preventing the LIDAR_CALIBRATION_REQUIRED fault from being re-reported.
Step 6: Clear the calibration required fault after running calibration.
Step 7: Verify all faults are cleared. Should return empty faults array (or only cleared faults if using ?status=all).
Step 8: View full fault history including cleared faults. All previously active faults should now show status=CLEARED.
